title: About the Course
body:
About the Course

Welcome to the Noise at Work e-learning package.

This e-learning package will enable you to understand the importance of hearing conservation in the work place, how noise in the work place can affect you, methods to protect your hearing from damage and have an overview of Rolls-Royce’s Hearing Conservation plan.

To complete this e-learning package you must complete all modules (including the ‘Test Your Knowledge’ module) and exit the course using the ‘exit’ button.

This e-learning package should take approximately 50 minutes to complete.

_button.text: Select the arrow to back to the Menu.

title: Objectives
body:
Objectives

Upon completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • explain the concept of noise;
  • describe the hearing process;
  • identify the effects of noise exposure on hearing; and
  • identify the types and signs of hearing loss.

This module should take approximately 10 minutes to complete.

title: What is Noise?
body:
Noise can be defined as any unwanted sound.

Noise at work may be a by-product of many industrial processes.

Exposure to high levels of noise may lead to hearing loss and other harmful health effects.

title: Parts of the Ear
body: The ear has three parts known as the outer ear, middle ear and inner ear.  Eardrum separates the outer ear from the middle ear.  All three parts of the ear work together to move sound from the external environment to the brain.
mobileBody: The ear has three parts known as the outer ear, middle ear and inner ear.  Eardrum separates the outer ear from the middle ear.  All three parts of the ear work together to move sound from the external environment to the brain.
instruction: Click each part of the ear for more information.
mobileInstruction: Click each part of the ear for more information.

_items.title: Outer Ear
_items.body: The outer ear is the fleshy visible part of the ear known as pinna or auricle.  It protects the eardrum.  This part of the ear collects sound and guides the sound waves to the middle ear.

_items.title: Middle Ear
_items.body: The middle ear includes an air-filled cavity and ossicles (3 attached tiny bones – malleus, incus and stapes).  Sound entering the outer ear travels through the middle ear and causes the eardrum and ossicles in the middle ear to vibrate.

_items.title: Eardrum
_items.body: Eardrum is a thin, cone-shaped membrane that separates the outer ear from the middle ear.  It transmits sound from the air to the ossicles inside the middle ear and then to the oval window in the fluid-filled cochlea.  It converts sound from air to liquid.

_items.title: Inner Ear
_items.body: The inner ear contains the cochlea that changes sound into neurological signals and sends it to the brain.  The fluid in the inner ear helps balance the ear organs and comprise the hearing, so it can be passed on to the nerves.

displayTitle: How Do We Hear?

title: How Do We Hear?
body: The process of hearing can be understood in five easy steps.
instruction: Click each step to learn about it.

_items.title: Step 1
_items.body: Sound waves enter the outer ear and travel through a narrow passageway called the ear canal that leads to the eardrum.

_items.title: Step 2
_items.body: The eardrum vibrates from the incoming sound waves and sends these vibrations to three tiny bones in the middle ear.

_items.title: Step 3
_items.body: The bones in the middle ear amplify, or increase, the sound vibrations and send them to the cochlea, a snail-shaped structure filled with fluid, in the inner ear.

_items.title: Step 4
_items.body: The cochlea contains tubes filled with fluid. Inside one of the tubes, tiny hair cells pick up the vibrations and convert them into nerve impulses.

_items.title: Step 5
_items.body: The auditory nerve carries these impulses to the brain that translates them into a sound that you recognise and understand.

title: Excessive Noise Exposure
body: Damage from noise exposure depends on the loudness and length of exposure.  The risk of hearing loss increases dramatically as noise levels increase.  Impact of various levels of noise can be examined as under:
mobileBody: Damage from noise exposure depends on the loudness and length of exposure.  The risk of hearing loss increases dramatically as noise levels increase.  Impact of various levels of noise can be examined as under:
instruction: Click each image to learn more.
mobileInstruction: Click each image to learn more.

_items.title: 85 Decibels and Above
_items.body: Scientific studies have shown that hearing loss can occur when the daily average noise exposure exceeds 85 decibels.

_items.title: 115 Decibels and Above
_items.body: Exposure to noise levels above 115 decibels for even five minutes is very risky.

_items.title: 140 Decibels and Above
_items.body: Impact or banging noise above 140 decibels will cause immediate damage to the nerves in the ear.

title: Effects on Noise Exposure
body:
Excessive noise exposure can lead to damaging of hair cells in the ears.

  • The tiny hair cells inside the cochlea move backwards and forwards in response to sound.
  • Exposure to high noise levels can damage the hair cells, impairing their ability to transmit nerve impulses to the brain.
  • This damage may lead to temporary or permanent hearing loss.

Other than damaging the hair cells, excessive noise exposure can also lead to tinnitus. People suffering from tinnitus usually complain of permanent ringing, constant whistling, squealing, roaring or buzzing in one or both ears. Severe tinnitus may disrupt sleep, reduce concentration and cause irritability and depression.

title: Types of Hearing Loss
displayTitle: Types of Hearing Loss
body:
Hearing loss can be defined as partial or total disability to hear.
Three types of hearing loss can be identified.
instruction: Click each card to learn more.

back.title: Temporary Threshold Shift (TTS)
back.body: This is a temporary hearing loss that may result from short-term exposures to noise. However, normal hearing may be resumed by staying away from noise exposure for some duration.

back.title: Acoustic Trauma
back.body: This type of hearing loss results from a short, intense sound, such as an explosion.

back.title: Permanent Threshold Shift (PTS)
back.body: This is a permanent hearing loss that happens gradually, through regular exposure to high noise levels, over a period of time.

title: Signs of Hearing Loss
displayTitle: Signs of Hearing Loss
body:
Hearing loss typically occurs over time. You may not even notice that you are losing your hearing capability.
Hence, you must ask yourself a few questions to look for signs of hearing loss.

If the answer to any of these questions is a ‘yes’, there is possibility that
you might be suffering from a hearing loss.

title: Common Noise Sources
body:
Working on certain machines or processes can lead to excessive noise exposure.

Some of the common sources of noise are:

title: Measurement of Sound
body: Sound is usually measured in decibels of sound pressure level (dB).
instruction: Click each tab for more information.

_items.title: dB Facts
_items.body:
• dB levels increase with an increase in the level of sound.
  • Human ear is more sensitive to certain frequencies than others.
  • When measuring sound, some frequencies are suppressed whilst others are enhanced. This is done to approximate to the response of the human ear.

_items.title: dB Weighting
_items.body:
• dB weightings can be identified as dB(A), dB(B), dB(C) and dB(D).
  • Usually, the dB weightings used at the workplace are dB(A) and dB(C).

title: Tools Used to Measure Noise
displayTitle: Tools Used to Measure Noise
body:
Noise can be measured by using tools like sound level meter, noise dosimeter or
a combination of both.
instruction: Click each card for more information.

back.title: Sound Level Meter
back.body: The sound level meter is usually held by the assessor in his hands. Its microphone is close to the operator’s ear.

back.title: Noise Dosimeter
back.body: The dosimeter is used to assess noise levels over a longer period. It is worn by the operator for an agreed time during the shift.

Objectives

Upon completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • explain the concept of hearing conservation at Rolls-Royce;
  • identify the risk criteria of excessive noise and ways to mitigate these risks;
  • describe noise assessment and its need; and
  • identify the content of a noise assessment report

This module should take approximately 10 minutes to complete.

title: Hearing Conservation at Rolls-Royce
body:
At Rolls-Royce, a hearing conservation program is designed to protect you from excessive noise that may lead to hearing loss. This program aims to:

  • Assess noise levels and exposures
  • Arrange for hearing tests to be carried out
  • Implement noise reduction plans
  • Provide hearing protection devices (HPDs)
  • Provide trainings on protection against hearing loss

For further details on hearing conservation at Rolls-Royce, refer to Noise at Work & Hearing Conservation Control Standard HSE CS 45.

title: Minimum Risk Criteria
body: At Rolls-Royce, the minimum risk criteria adopted is as follows.
instruction: Click each image for more information.

back.title: Lower Exposure Action Values
back.body:
Daily time weighted average equivalent to 8 hours or weekly personal noise exposure of:
80dB(A) to 85dB(A)

Instantaneous, peak, sound pressure level of:
135dB(C) to 137dB(C)

back.title: Upper Exposure Action Values
back.body:
Daily time weighted average equivalent to 8 hours or weekly personal noise exposure of:
More than 85dB(A)

Instantaneous, peak, sound pressure level of:
More than 137dB(C)

back.title: Exposure Limit Values
back.body:
Daily time weighted average equivalent to 8 hours or weekly personal noise exposure of:
More than 87dB(A)

Instantaneous, peak, sound pressure level of:
More than 140dB(A)

Exposure Limit Values: These values express the maximum allowed exposure to the ear. They take into account the protection received from wearing any hearing protection device.

displayTitle: Actions for Mitigating Risks

title: Actions for Mitigating Risks
body: At Rolls-Royce, two areas are classified for mitigating the risks arising from excessive noise exposure.
instruction: Click each step to learn about it.

_items.title: Areas exceeding one or both of the Lower Exposure Action Values but below the Upper Exposure Action Values
_items.body:
To mitigate risks in these areas:

  • Use suitable, clearly visible signs and floor markings, where appropriate.
  • Implement prioritised noise reduction measures and reduce exposures to as low as reasonably practicable. (This must be in addition to the use of hearing protection devices).
  • Ask for hearing protection devices available on request for all employees working in these areas.
  • Attend trainings conducted periodically for noise awareness.

    • For guidance on noise reduction techniques, refer to HSE CS 45-03.

_items.title: Areas exceeding one or both of the Upper Exposure Action Values
_items.body:
These shall be designated as Noise Hazard Areas. To mitigate risks in these areas:

  • Use suitable, clearly visible signs and floor markings, where appropriate.
  • Identify the conditions, under which the Noise Hazard Area is applied, on the sign. For example, an area may be designated as a Noise Hazard Area when a machine is operating. This is to ensure that Noise Hazard Area is not in force at all times.
  • Create department/site layout drawings to indicate the Noise Hazard Areas. Display these drawings at appropriate prominent locations.
  • Implement prioritised noise reduction measures and reduce exposures to as low as reasonably practicable. (This must be in addition to the use of hearing protection devices).
  • Wear hearing Protection Devices (HPDs) at all times while working in or visiting Noise Hazard Areas.
  • List all employees identified as being exposed to noise at or above the Upper Exposure Action Value in the Health Assessment Register.
  • Attend audiometry testing.
  • Attend trainings conducted periodically for noise awareness.

For guidance on Mandatory Signs, refer to HSE CS 45-03.

title: Noise Assessments
body:
All individuals and areas exposed to noise exposure must be assessed periodically, as a minimum requirement of the noise assessments plan. Noise assessments need to be carried out:



At least once every two years.

Whenever a significant change occurs.

Whenever there is a reason to believe that the current assessment is no longer valid.

title: Need for Noise Assessments
body: Noise assessments are essential to ensure safety from excessive noise exposure.
mobileBody: Noise assessments are essential to ensure safety from excessive noise exposure.
instruction: Click each question for more information.
mobileInstruction: Click each question for more information.

_items.title: When is a noise assessment required?
_items.body:
A noise assessment is required when:
  • People have to raise their voices to be heard.
  • People have difficulty being heard.
  • Loud noises occur from high pressure gases.
  • Loud impact noises occur.

_items.title: Who/What is assessed in a noise assessment?
_items.body:
A noise assessment is used to assess:
  • All individuals/groups, if there is a possibility that one of the noise exposure values may be exceeded.
  • Areas where the noise level may exceed one of the noise exposure values and might contribute to an employee’s exposure. For example, a compressor house exceeding the exposure value of 85dB(A). Noise mapping is required in all such areas.
  • Areas adjacent to where noisy activities are being carried out to ensure that they are not affected by hazardous noise. Noise mapping is required in all such areas.

title: Noise Assessments Report
body:
The result of noise assessments is compiled in a report and is issued to the manager of the concerned area. The noise assessments report identifies and records the following information:

People/Group/Area assessed
Date of the assessment
Number of People/Group/Area assessed
Action levels (Below Exposure, Lower Exposure and Upper Exposure)
People/Group/Area exceeding Exposure Limit Values
Each significant noise source contributing to the noise exposure, its noise level and any instantaneous peaks
Durations of exposure to significant noise sources (daily work periods given as definite time, range or maximum)
Daily/Weekly equivalent noise exposures and/or the instantaneous peak
Number of employees identified as exposed at or above the Upper Exposure Action Value
Any conditions under which the noise may or may not cause a noise hazard
Information to assist effective targeting of noise reduction control measures
Details of the noise meter or dosimeter used and their last calibration date

title: Objectives

Objectives

Upon completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • explain the prevention and control measures for noise exposure;
  • identify measures to protect personnel from noise exposure;
  • describe the concept of audiometric testing; and
  • recognise your role in hearing conservation.

This module should take approximately 10 minutes to complete.

displayTitle: Prevention of Noise Exposure

title: Prevention of Noise Exposure
body: It is better to prevent excessive noise exposure at the outset rather than facing its hazards at a later stage. Noise exposure can be successfully contained by taking certain preventive measures.
instruction: Click each preventive measure for more information.

_items.title: Purchase of New Equipment
_items.body:
While purchasing new equipment, the following points must be considered to prevent excessive noise exposure.

  • New machine tools, plant and equipment must not exceed the noise level of 80dB(A).
  • Areas where new equipment is introduced should have a noise level of below 80dB(A).
  • At times maintaining a level of 80dB(A) may not be achievable. In such cases, noise control must be included in the specification to reduce the noise level to as close to 80dB(A) as possible.
  • Equipment suppliers must be informed of noise and operational requirements.

_items.title: Reduction of Noise at Source
_items.body:
Noise levels can be maintained within the acceptable range by reducing the noise at source. This can be achieved by adopting engineering modifications that can alter the process of noise generation. Engineering modifications include:

  • impacts – presses and mechanical handling;
  • rotating machines – gears, pumps, bearings and electric motors; and
  • friction forces – cutting tools and brakes.

_items.title: Other Preventive Measures
_items.body:
Prevention of noise exposure can also be achieved by:

  • elimination or substitution of the noisy activity;
  • silencing technique;
  • enclosure of noisy equipment;
  • screening of noisy equipment from the employee;
  • increased separation of the employee from the noise source; and
  • absorption of noise by cladding of appropriate surfaces with sound absorbent material.

title: Control of Noise Exposure
displayTitle: Control of Noise Exposure
body: In addition to the preventive measures, noise exposure can also be kept within acceptable range through several control measures.

title: Protection of Personnel at Risk
displayTitle: Protection of Personnel at Risk
body:
Personnel are at a risk of hearing loss from excessive noise exposure and need to be protected. This can be achieved by:

  • Provision of Noise refuges in designated areas
  • Alteration of work patterns
  • Use of Personal Hearing Protection Devices (ear muffs, ear plugs etc)
